Spice and its effects on breast cancer

Summary generated using: $shovel3 query.concatConclusions 'breast cancer spice site:ncbi.nlm.nih.gov' 40 includeReference=True
  • Cloves are natural products with excellent cytotoxicity toward MCF-7 cells; thus, they are promising sources for the development of anticancer agents.
    • Journal:
    • Date:
    • Link to article
  • Mitochondrial toxicity may be part of the mechanism by which the spices tested cause inhibition of proliferation and death in the cell lines tested. This study also warrants caution in the excessive use of these spices for human consumption. Copyright © 2012 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
    • Journal: Food and Chemical Toxicology
    • Date: 03/29/15
    • Link to article
  • The studied plants are potential cytotoxic drugs that deserve more detailed exploration in the future, to develop novel anticancer drugs against sensitive and otherwise drug-resistant phenotypes. Copyright © 2013 Elsevier Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.
    • Journal: Journal of Ethnopharmacology
    • Date: 04/27/15
    • Link to article
  • We suggest that curcumin be tested as a dietary chemopreventive agent in women already exposed to MPA in an effort to decrease or delay the risk of breast cancer associated with combined HRT.
